div.head: Regarding the text
div.p:
Praeterea diligenter Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 1, n. 1 . This is distinction 14 which with respect to the preceding continues in the following way. For after the Master determined about the eternal emanation of the Holy Spirit, now he begins to treat about his temporal mission. And this is divided into two parts because first he shows that the Holy Spirit is given specially to human beings from the Father and the Son, in the second place he asks whether it is able to be given by holy human beings. The second part begins at
hic quaeritur utrum viri sancti Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 3, n. 1 . The first is divided into two parts because in the first place he offers his intention about the beginning of this temporal mission, in the second place he refutes a false opinion drawn from what he has proposed. The second begins at
sunt aliqui Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 2, n. 1 .

The second principal part is divided in three parts, for in the first place he shows that the Holy Spirit is not able to be given by a mere creature, in the second place he shows how the authority of the Apostle seems contrary to this. In the third place he shows how this should be explained. The second begins at
sed huic videtur esse contrarium Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 3, n. 4 . The third begins at
sed intelligendum est Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 3, n. 4 , etc.

Whether the temporal mission of the Holy Spirit in the heart of the faithful is an eternal procession not having a beginning? Whether the temporal donation the Holy Spirit in the heart of the faithful is of the same eternal spiration that comes from the Father and the Son?

That not because the Holy Spirit is not given nor sent temporally to creatures, therefore. The antecedent is proved because, if this were true, either such a giving would require some prior disposition in the receiving creature, or some nature. If the first, it follows that it is a disposition of a disposition, and thus there will be an infinite process in such prerequisite dispositions or there will be some disposition that can be given absolutely not presupposing a prior disposition, and then it will be able to be said similarly about the giving of the Holy Spirit that it is will be a first not requiring a prior. If the second, it follows that one will be equally capable of receiving the Holy Spirit
whether indisposed or disposed, which is false, therefore. In the second place, the antecedent is proved because, if the Holy Spirit were given to a creature, it would follows that it would be united to itself as habitual charity, which is false.

In the second place principally, it is argued therefore the Holy Spirit would be given either with its own gift or with nothing or with something and not something. Not the first then the Holy Spirit would coexist with the gift of fear, which is false because charity expels fear. Not the second because then contraries would be verified about the same thing without change or a new position of the thing against the article. Nor the third because the argument is not greater for one thing than for another, therefore.

In the third place principally, it is as repugnant to be eternally given in time as it is to be given or proceed temporally as eternal, but the first is impossible, therefore. The antecedent is clear because a person proceeding and everything temporal is mutable, as says
Augustine IV De Trinitate, in chapter 2
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 2, xxx .

In opposition is
the Master in this distinction Lombardus, I, d. 14, xxx
And this is confirmed because things which differ in reason alone are really different. But the temporal sending of the Holy Spirit and the eternal procession are of this type, therefore. The minor is clear because when the procession of the Holy Spirit terminates in an eternal object it is called eternal, but when it terminates in a temporal object it is called temporal.

First conclusion: it is the case that any incomplex gift of the Holy Spirit formally inheres in the rational creature and through this gift the creature is not able to be gratified by God. This is proved because it is the case that any created incomplex gift is able to be conserved and to not be accepted as agreeable to himself by the same one, therefore. This is confirmed because only God suffices to justify and elevate the mind gratuitiously, therefore.

The first corollary: though the Holy Spirit or the uncreated gift is only sufficient for gratification, nevertheless it does not inhere in the mind through the mode of a gift or habitual grace. The first part is clear because the mind is pleasing to God prior to the created charity given to it, therefore. This is confirmed because God does not choose us from time, but before the constitution of the world Ephesios 1:4
according to the
Apostle . The second part is proven because it is a kind of imperfection to inhere in a manner other than through the mode of habit, therefore from God this should be entirely denied.

The second corollary: no incomplex created gift of the Holy Spirit is formally and intrinsically repugnant to or incompossible with damnation or guilt. This is clear because every thing that is repugnant is intrinsically able to gratify and and sufficient for the expulsion of guilt.

Third corollary: no created grace nor some created gift suffices through itself to remove guilt or mortal sin. This is clear because, through
the preceding corollary See above , sin is compossible with any such created gift, such as created charity.

The second conclusion: though the Holy Spirit is the effective causal ratio of all his gifts, nevertheless it is not a necessary connexive ratio existing in them all at the same time. This is clear through Prima patet per illud Ephesians 2
For we are his workmanship created in Christ Jesus in good works which God prepared so that we would walk in them
Ephesians 2:10
about which Augustine says:
non utique illa creatione qua homines facti sumus sed de ea ipse dicebat qui iam homo erat
create in me a clean heart, O God Psalmus 50:12
Augustinus, De Gratia et Libro Arbitrio, I, 8, 20 . The second part is proved because the Holy Spirit does not have a greater nor a more necessary connection with respect to one than with respect to all, but it does not have a necessary connection with respect to all according to the
Apostole, I Corinthians, in chapter 1
saying that there are divisions among grace. And it follows
But all things work with one and the same Spirit, who divides to everyone as it wills
I Corinthians 12:11 , where it is also clear in each part of the conclusion.

The first corollary: it stands that the Holy Spirit descends to the rational mind and does not communicate to it any gratituous incomplexly created gift. This is clear because between this there is no necessary and absolute connection through communication. This is confirmed because the Holy Spirit communicates his gift most freely, not only what he wills, but even when he wills according to the Apostolum,
see above See above , therefore.

Second corollary: it stands that the gift of the Holy Spirit is diffused in the rational mind and the person of the Holy Spirit is not infused through this special descending into the same mind. This is clear because gifts are distinct from it. Again, gifts do not have a necessary connection, such that they necessarily exist in the same thing at the same time, therefore.

Third corollary: although the Holy Spirit is able to be communicated with any of its gratuitious incomplexly created gift, nevertheless the Holy Spirit is not able to be given without some other gratuitious gift. The first part is clear through what has been said. The second part is proved because it is impossible that the Holy Spirit is given to the rational mind with innovation or renovation through which there is created in it a clean heart and a just being. But this some complex gift of the Holy Spirit. For example, that the mind just and pleasing to God.

Third conclusion: though the sending by which the Holy Spirit is communicated to men temporally from its same eternal procession is not really distinguished, nevertheless the sending or gratuitous diffusion of this type is improperly referred to as temporal. The first part is proved because the indivisible simplicity is not properly nor really distinguishable from itself, and the mission of the Holy Spirit, etc. is of this type. The major is known. The minor is proved because otherwise the Holy Spirit would at sometime begin to have a disposition or real production which it did not have from eternity, which is false. The second part is clear through
the Master in the first chapter of distinction 14
where he says
this production is temporal
Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 1, n. 5
. But this is not able to be said properly and intrinsically, therefore improperly and terminatively of some new extrinsic relation, which is what has been proposed.

The first corollary: it is possible that the Holy Spirit produces in the mind of a just pilgrim as perfectly as the Holy Spirit is produced in the original font of the highest spiration. This is clear because it is produced by the same production really and nominally in the mind of the pilgrim and in the font of inspiration.

The second corollary: that the eternal emanation of the Holy Spirit is the temporal justification or gratification of holy men. This is clear because the diffusion of the Holy Spirit in the mind is the gratification of the mind, and this is not really anything other than its eternal emanation, therefore.

Third corollary: although the gratuitious diffusion of the Holy Spirit made to holy men is called and was a temporal procession of the Holy Spirit, nevertheless in no way is this or is this able to be changeable. The same thing is clear with eternal procession, which is entirely unchangeable, therefore. From these things the affirmative title of the question follows.

To the principal argument, the antecedent, the antecedent is denied. And to the proof it is said through the third conclusion that at least from the absolute power and law of God the Holy Spirit is able to be communicated and to be sent without these gifts, and conversely because there is no necessary connection between these, and nevertheless it does not follow from this that it is against the article because without the position of a new thing contradictories are able to be verified sinece when taking thing loosely, as if extending to the mode of the thing, this giving of the Holy Spirit would not occur without some complex created gift because it would confer to the mind just and pleasing being and this suffices for the article, nevertheless it would occur without a habitual incomplex created gift, as is said in
the third corollary of the third conclusion
Vide supra .

Against the first conclusion: it is argued in the first place thus that it suffices that to elevate the mind to some point of acting meritoriously it is the efficient principle and is sufficiently gratifying and gratuitously elevating of the mind. But a gift of gratuitously caused grace is of this type. Proof: because the created gift elevates so intensely for the power to act well, just as to be well, and conversely, therefore when it elevates to intrinsecally being well, thus it leads to doing well, and in this what is proposed is reached.

Against the first corollary: the uncreated form is not mediately or immediately uniteable to a subject, therefore there is required a first disposition of the gift or of the uncreated form. Therefore the Holy Spirit by itself is not able to gratify the mind or deliver grace.

Against the second corollary: created charity is a greater good than the remission of guilt, therefore this has sufficient imputability or activity for the remission of guilt. The consequence is clear. The antecedent is proved because through created charity the mind is more perfected and more supernaturally elevated than through the remission of guilt.

Against the third corollary: it follows that the habit of charity is not effective of a meritorious act, which is false, because the assistance does not suffice for operating meritoriously. The consequence is proved since a meritorious act seems intrinsically and formally gratuitous because it does not seem impossible that an act is meritorious of eternal life
and not meritorious or gratuitious.

To the first, the minor is denied, and to the proof, the consequence is denied. But it ought to be concluded thus and the minor ought to be formed, but sufficiently through itself it intrinsically elevates to being well morally, therefore to operating, and arguing in this way the minor is denied.

To the second, I say that if it understands about gratuitious union through the sanctification of the mind, about which now is the word, then the antecedent is denied not only because God is an agent of infinite power but also because the soul is as if an immediate subject in that union, and again because the agent is said to be where it works, but God works in us every good disposition, therefore it is in us earlier than such dispositions.

To the third, having conceded the antecedent, the consequence is denied because, if it were valid, it would be proved in a similar way that man would suffice for producing some individual of a species inferior to itself. The consequence is clear because man is more perfect than those things, for example a horse or an ass.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied, and to the proof, it is said that when taking such an act as an incomplex entity, in this case the act is not formally intrinsically gratuitous, but extrinsically and denotatively, namely because is the kind of thing accepted from God and because one freely accepts and is able to not accept. Therefore it stands that such an entity is and is not meritorious.

Against the second conclusion, it is argued in the first place thus, it is impossible that some creature is and God does not exist in it through its present power and essence, therefore. The antecedent is clear through
the Master in distinction 37 of the first book Lombardus, I, d. 37 . The consequence is clear both because these kinds of gratuituous gifts are things and because they are true things to those to whom they are given, therefore the Holy Spirit will be in those things as in gifts, therefore one is not given without the other.

Against the first corollary: because it would follows that something would be able to have a gratuitous being without a gratuitous form. The consequent is false because the
form is that which gives the being of the thing
Peter of Spain, Summulae Logicales, Tractatus 5 (De Rijk, 68)
. The consequence is clear because the habitual gratuitious form is a gratituous created gift of God, and anyone who has the Holy Spirit has the gratuitous being, therefore.

Against the second, it follows that some habitual form would inform the subject and it would not be called this or that something without the Spirit would be able to merit eternal life, each is false. The consequence is proved because since love is the gift Holy Spirit, if this is had without the Holy Spirit, then either it would render that one sufficiently beloved for eternal life or not. If not, then it would follow that charity does not denote one who is beloved, which is the first inconvenience. If so, then the second inconvenience follows, namely that such a person would merit, while not having, eternal life, that is the Holy Spirit.

Against the third corollary, it is asked what is this gratuitous gift? Either it is the Holy Spirit precisely, and then it follows that without distinction or position, etc, against the articule, as Gregory infers, or it is the mind itself elevated through the Holy Spirit, or something else emerging from all these things. The second is not given because then the mind would gratify itself nor is the third able to be said, therefore.

To the first, the consequence is denied, and to the proof, I say that here I do not speak about this in the common mode of being by which God is in all things, but about this in the way Christ is spoken of,
if anyone loves me etc. we will make our abode among him
Ioannes 14:23
about which Brother Jordan our doctor says that such a gratuitous union is to mind greater than it is or was the divine hypostatic union to the supposite, not only because in this union not just one person is united and comes but the entire trinity, on account of which it is said we come, but also because in this union it comes on account of him, to him, and in him. Third because it does not come only to return, but will remain eternally, therefore it is said,
among him we will make our abode
Ioannes 14:23 . Therefore it would be able to be said that this special mode of being is the intimation in the heart of created and uncreated charity and some diffusion of the immeasurable divine sweetness and some refraction in the intellect of the divine light, such that anyone perceiving and accepting this would be able to say that Psalm
God you, turning, will bring us to life
Psalmus 84:7
This point is made by
Master
Herman of Schildesche on the Song of Songs chapter 4 ,
to the beloved, and his turning is to me
Hermanus de Schildesche, xxx .

To the second, it is said that, that someone has gratituous being, is able to be in two ways. In one mode, habitually, intrinsically, and informatively, in another mode, extrinsically and denotively. In the first mode, the consequence is denied. In the second mode, the consequence is conceded, and the consequent and its proof work in the first mode, not in the second, because such a soul would be called good extrinsically and causally through the Holy Spirit, nevertheless not formally or informally.

To the third, it could be said in one mode that from the absolute power of God the consequent is possible for the first part. In another mode, the antecedent is able to be conceded because someone would be able to reach eternal life while not having the Holy Spirit in this mode of having it. In a third mode, is able to be said that the principle denomination of created love is not that we are loved by God, but because God is loved by us, and thus the first consequent does not follow.
To the fourth, it is said that none of them is, but there is some other mode by which God makes the soul just and freely and gratuitiously accepted by him into eternal life, and this suffices.

Against the third conclusion, it is argued in the first place thus, there is a double procession of the Holy Spirit, therefore one is distinct from the other. The consequence is clear from the terms, and the antecedent from the
Master in this distinction
Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 1 . This is confirmed because processions are counted according to terms, just as it is possible to see from
IVPhysics Aristoteles, Physicorum, IV, xxx
concerning motions.
But temporal and eternal processions are different kinds of terms according to
Commentator X Metaphysicae Averroes, Metaphysicae, X
corruptible and incorruptible differ more than in kind, therefore the conclusion is false.

Against the first corollary, it follows that God would not produce the Holy Spirit more perfectly in the soul of one just person than any other. The consequent is false because it follows that the Holy Spirit was not more perfectly in the soul of Christ than he was in the soul of Peter

Against the second corollary, it follows that the gratification of man would be eternal and immeasurable. The consequent is false because then man would be immeasurably pleasing to God, and thus one person would not be more pleasing than any other.

Against the third corollary, there is
Augustine IV City of God, in chapter three
Augustinus, De civitate Dei, IV, c. 2
who approves the word of
Apuleus who says in his book On the World
all earthly things are subject to change upheaval and destruction Apuleius, On the World, 34 , therefore since according to Augustine every temporal thing is changeable, it follows that, if the procession of the Holy Spirit is temporal, that it is changeable.

To the first, it is said that the Master wishes to say that the Holy Spirit proceeds in two modes and nevertheless in a single procession. To the confirmation, the antecedent is conceded where what is proceeding is referred to such terms really and intrinsically rather than extrinsically according to reason alone. Whence according to
Augustine V De Trinitate, in the last chapter capitulo ultimo Augustinus, De Trinitate, V, c. xxx , the Holy Spirit refers to an eternal object according to its being, but to a temporal object only according to reason.

To the second, I say that such a production is able to be considered in four ways, in the first mode with respect to act, with respect to the term, with respect to the mode of production, and with respect to the fruit of production. In the first or second mode the consequent is able to be conceded, but not in the third or fourth mode, and nor do I wish to say so.

To the third, I say that it follows well that the gratification of man is immeasurable, but is not an immeasurable gratification of man. It would be able to be said similarly about beatitude, and many other things, that the beatitude of man is immeasurable, but is not, etc.
To the last, I say that Augustine is speaking about the temporal properly and intrinsically, but the procession of the Holy Spirit is not the kind about which he is speaking.

To the first in the opposition, the antecedent is denied, and when it is said because this kind of giving presupposes etc., it is true from the common and ordered law, and an infinite process is denied.
To another, the consequence is denied.
To the third, it is clear through what has been said that it is possible that charity is in some subject and such a subject is not pleasing or loved.
To another the solution is clear through what has been said.

To the last, the antecedent is denied for the first part because nothing proceeds while it is not, but no temporal thing has
had being from eternity, but temporality is able to coincide with the eternal, not intrinsically, but extrinsically or by some extrinsic denomination, without changing itself.

Praeterea diligenter Lombardus, I, d. 14, c. 1, n. 1 . etc. This distinction contains five conclusions. The first that there is a twofold procession of the Holy Spirit, one eternal procession by which it proceeds eternally from the Father and the Son and does so without time, another temporal one by which it proceeds commonly or at the same time temporally from the Father and the Son for sanctifying a creature, and this procession is a called a mission.

Second conclusion: that Christ initiated this temporal procession since after the resurrection he breathed upon his disciples saying
receive the Holy Spirit John 20:22
Iohannis. Again the Holy Spirit itself is this power which from Christ
emerged and cleansed all people
Lucas 6:19
Luce
6 8
.

Third conclusion: that Christ, so that he would show this temporal procession of the Holy Spirit is not other than giving of this power, after the resurrection gave himself one time on earth on account of love of the neighbor, and another time from heaven on account of the love of God on the day of Pentacost.

Fourth conclusion: that the gifts of the only the gifts of the Holy Spirit are given to us, but also the Holy Spirit is given to us who is equal to the Father and the Son and is the third person in the Trinity against some holding the opposite position.

Fifth conclusion: that holy men and prelates are not able to give the Holy Spirit nor do they have the authority of giving, though they have the ministry, because sometimes it is give by God through some ministerially and instrumentally, and sometimes it is given through others, etc.
